awd_titl_txt: RAPID: STEM faculty support to address impacts from COVID-19 on Tribal Colleges and Universities Program institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the STEM curricular offerings at these institutions expands the opportunities of their students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be culturally significant, and encourages a community and generational appreciation for science and mathematics education. The sustainability of STEM instructional capacity gains is significantly enhanced by retaining the talent of credentialed STEM faculty. This project aligns directly with that goal.

The COVID-19 pandemic caused major disruptions to institutions of higher education. For tribal colleges and universities, whose core operating funds are directly aligned with student enrollment, drops in enrollment equate to loss of funding. To mitigate against detrimental pandemic-related effects on STEM instructional capacity, this award will support the salary and professional development of one full-time STEM faculty member at Salish Kootenai College. This TCUP STEM Faculty award is intended to help maintain Salish Kootenai College’s STEM program as the college recovers from the deleterious impact of the pandemic.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The RAPID award to support TCU faculty after the COVID pandemic has been successful in retaining faculty to improve and sustain the quality of education for undergraduate students in the Life Sciences at Salish Kootenai College (SKC). Importantly, the Life Sciences program engages undergraduate students in novel research projects. The faculty member supported by this award was able to mentor and train students on an ongoing project studying an extremophile microorganism isolated from the superfund site, the Berkeley Pit in Butte, Montana. Moreover, the supported faculty member was successful in completing the paper writing for past results on the project resulting in a publication in Microbiology Spectrum, a scientific journal. Overall, this was a very successful award that supported key activities through a Life Sciences faculty member thereby supporting the Life Sciences program, undergraduate research mentorship, and improving institutional capacity through research publication.

The research publication to Microbiology Spectrum has led to a continuation of the H. anomala project. This project has now received funding from two other sources and will be forwarded throughout the next two years to investigate survival genes and natural bioproducts. Both of these projects have recently begun and involve two students as well as the orginally funded faculty member by the RAPID grant. It is a great success to have the research and education continue at SKC and will lead to future publications to forward the undergraduate student careers in science thereby supporting underrepresented populations in science.
